2 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN January 1, 1929. From: The Adjutant General of Nebraska. To: His Excellency, Arthur J. Weaver, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska, Subject: Biennial Report of 1927 and 1928. 1. In compliance with the requirements of Section No. 3305, Chapter 34, article 1, revised Statutes of Nebraska, 1922, the follow - ing Biennial Report for the calendar years 1927 and 1928 is respect - fully submitted. 2. During the past two years, the National Guard of Nebraska has reached a high standard of efficiency and in its development has made most gratifying progress. Each year, training has materially improved and in a logical and progressive manner. The community interest in our units and the moral assistance of committees of Chambers of Commerce in the cities where the units are located, as well as many where no troops are stationed, has been most helpful. 3. The character of supply and equipment is not altogether satis - factory as we are still using war time stock and the uniforms, in my opinion, should be classed as shoddy; however, the Federal Gov - ernment has promised us new uniforms for our enlisted men in 1930 and I am sure these will prove most beneficial. The ordnance is of the best and since the Federal Government has allowed us caretakers in the form of motor mechanics, all trucks have been placed in the best condition possible, and notwithstanding the fact that they were issued from the World War supply, are considered serviceable in case of an emergency. 4. By virtue of the National Defense Act and Miltia Bureau regulations, the Adjutant General of Nebraska, under the direction of the Governor, is required to execute the approved policies of the War Department as well as the laws of Nebraska in so far as applic - able to the National Guard. In addition to this, records of veterans

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 3 of the Civil War, Spanish American War and World War are kept in this office and we are daily called upon for certified copies of these records. A complete record of all Federal property issued to the National Guard, as well as all funds allotted to the State, is also kept in this office. The amount of property accounted for, and now in the State, is over a million dollars in value and the aanoscf'~disburse - ment from Federal funds is something over five hundred thousand dollars; this in addition to the training programs required, supervision of training of the National Guard units during their armory drills and being in charge of the annual field training, gives some idea of the work performed by this office, and is handled by total personnel of six, which is much less than most States with a like number of units employ. CAMP ASHLAND Additional improvement has been made at this camp site by the Federal Government including a permanent kitchen and mess hall for each company, two kitchens and mess halls for officers, an admin - istration building, and contracts have now been let for supply houses. OTHER FUXDS Since the passage of the act by the last session of the legislature, making it possible for the Governor of the State to receive from the Federal Government monies taken from the Nebraska units during the World War which were known as "other funds", the Government has returned to the reconstituted units of Nebraska approximately |30,000. Every unit in Nebraska voted to return these funds to the Adjutant General of Nebraska, as trustee, to be used in the con - struction of a memorial building at Ashland, which will be used as a welfare building and recreation hall; this building will be in memory of the veterans of the World War who created the fund, thereby mak - ing it possible to have it returned to the present organizations. IXSPKCTIOXS Annual armory inspections are made by Officers of the United States Army detailed for that purpose. The results of our last armory inspections evidenced close conformity to schedules and gave the Ne - braska National Guard a very satisfactory rating. ARMORIES As reported before, the most discouraging proposition with which the units of the Nebraska National Guard have to contend is the rental of armories. It is almost impossible to rent suitable buildings

4 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL at reasonable rentals for armories for the National Guard units which .give adequate protection to Government property that the State is required to protect, and, at the same time, have ample space for armory drills and training. In this regard, Nebraska is behind many of the other States who have constructed armories and the State is frequently criticized by in - spectors on this account. It will be much cheaper in the long run for the State to construct its own armories and we expect to intro - duce a constructional program in the near future which we hope our legislature will give favorable consideration. UNITED STATES ARMY OFFICERS AND SERGEANT INSTRUCTORS DETAILED TO THE STATE The following is a list of United States Army Officers and Sergeant instructors who are detailed by the War Department to the State of Nebraska for instructional purposes and who render very valuable service and have done much to assist in placing the Nebraska National Guard at its present high standing among the other States ot the union. Lt. Col. Morris M. Keck, Inf. DOL., Lincoln, Nebr. Major Emil H. Burgher, MC. DOL., Lincoln, Nebr. Capt. McGregor Snodgrass, QMC. DOL., Lincoln, Nebr. Capt. Leo J. Farrell, Inf. DOL., Omaha, Nebr. Master Sgt. Lee R. G. Ward, Inf. DEML., Omaha, Nebr. Sergeant Emet G. Roach, Inf. DEML., Lincoln, Nebr. Sergeant Zack Scarborough, MC. DEML., Lincoln, Nebr. Sergeant Hjalmar Strom, QMC. DEML., Lincoln, Nebr. ARMORY DRILL Armory drill attendance has shown a steady increase during the past year and has exceeded the expectations of both the State and Federal authorities. Assemblies are held each week on regular sched - ule for each unit. Programs are prepared by regimental and bat - talion commanders and schedules are submitted in advance covering the detail instruction given. Under the United States laws, each officer and enlisted man is allowed a day's pay by the Federal govern - ment for each drill attended. Attendance is mandatory and penalties are provided for non-performance. CONCLUSION In conclusion I wish to express my appreciation to the officers and enlisted men of the National Guard, and to the officers and non-

14 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 2. Lieutenant Hoffman enlisted in Company F, 2nd Ne - braska Infantry, June 23, 1910. Appointed Corporal October 20, 1910; appointed Sergeant September 16, 1911. Honorably discharged June 22, 1913, expiration term of enlistment. En - listed in Headquarters Detachment, 110th Medical Regiment, Nebraska National Guard, June 29, 1923. Appointed Sergeant, August 10, 1923. Transferred to Service Co., 110th Medical Regiment, June 1, 1924. Honorably discharged June 28, 1924, expiration of enlistment. Re-enlisted in Service Co., 110th Med - ical Regiment, July 3, 1924. Warrant as Sergeant continued on re-enlistment. Honorably discharged April 18, 1926, to accept commission. Appointed 1st Lieutenant, Medical Administra - tive Corps, and assigned to Hospital Co. No. 130, 110th Med - ical Regiment, April 19, 1926. Served to date of death, August 7, 1927. 3. Lieutenant Hoffman earned his commission in the National Guard of this State through his energy and pain- National Guard of this State through his energy and pains - taking efforts to always make good in every grade he was filling, and while he had only been a commissioned officer a little over a year, he had thoroughly demonstrated that the trust was well made and he had demonstrated his fitness as a Medi - cal Administrative officer. 4. Lieutenant Hoffman will long be remembered as one of the efficient officers of the Nebraska National Guard, the sym - pathy of which is extended to his family in this their hour of sorrow. On page 48, Report of the Chief of Militia Bureau for the Fiscal Year ended June 30, 1926, attention was directed to the large number of Reports of Survey and Inventory and Inspection reports re - ceived and acted upon in the Militia Bureau, during the period covered by the report. The information outlined above was placed in the Report of the Chief, Militia Bureau, in the hopes that the situation would be brought to the attention of responsible officers of the National Guard in the various States, with a view to improving the situation in this important matter. I am happy to say that several States have already Office of the Chief of the Militia Bureau Washington n Reply refer January 26, 1927. ro MB 400.241 Neb. -1 Subject: Care of Public Property and Distribursement of Publt Funds. ro: The Adjutant General of Nebraska.

During the past year a comparatively large number of irregul - arities in the disbursement and expenditure of public funds have been brought to the attention of the Militia Bureau through investigations conducted by the Department of Justice and by the Inspector General's Department of the Army. These irregularities have involved the pay - ment for attentance at armory drill, the payment of caretakers and the sale of public property. In some cases the State authorities con - cerned have initiated suitable disciplinary action; in others, indict - ments have been obtained and cases have been prosecuted in the courts. In the recent debate in the House of Representatives on the War Department Appropriations Bill, with special reference to items pertaining to the National Guard, the charge was made on the floor of the House of Representatives that there was wholesale padding: of pay rolls and fraudulent payments to enlisted men as caretakers. While such accusations were properly answered at the time, the number of irregularities brought to light during the past fiscal year is undoubtedly responsible for the impression in certain quarters that there is laxity in handling of public funds in the National Guard. Of course I cannot condone such irregularities nor can I intervene to protect individuals. At the same time I am very much concerned lest these continued irregularities shall have the effect of bringing the good name of the National Guard into disrepute and cause a loss of the public confidence. In my opinion, these are matters of primary importance to all officers of the National Guard and particularly to those in positions of responsibility. 4. The primary purpose of this letter is to bring these matters to your attention and to suggest that you insist that all officers charged with responsibility for public property in the hands of the National Guard, for the preparation of pay rolls, for disbursement and ex - penditure of public funds, and for delivery of pay checks, must exer - cise the greatest care and do all in their power to prevent the loss of public property, irregular disbursements and expenditures. 60 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN October 18, 1927. Circular Letter No. 27. Subject: Limitation of Armory Drills. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, Nebraska National Guard. 1. Inviting attention to copy of letter received from The Chief, Militia Bureau, relative to Limitation of Armory Drills. WAR DEPARTMENT Militia Bureau Washington MB 240.91-Mo.-ll October 10, 1927. Subject: Limitation of Armory Drills. To: The Adjutant General of Nebraska, (Thru the Commanding General, Seventh Corps Area) 1. There has been some misunderstanding of the provisions of Militia Bureau letters MB 240.91 of May 28, 1926, February 9, 1927 and May 5, 1927, on Limitation of Armory Drills. 2. Because of the phrasing of the letters, it has been construed in some quarters that the Secretary of War through the Chief, Militia Bureau, was limiting the number of assemblies which might be held during a certain quarter or year. (See Par. 11, NGR. 45). The letters were not intended to convey such a meaning. While each organization is required to hold the minimum number of assemblies authorized from time to time by the Secretary of War, the State authorities may prescribe as many more assemblies for a unit as they desire. The Secretary of War in the letters above referred to prescribed the maxi - mum number of assemblies for which Federal pay is authorized within the limits of available appropriations, which number is also the mini - mum number of assemblies which must be held. The letters while un - fortunately using the phrase "the number of drills to be held", do not limit the number of assemblies which may be held by an organization. 3. However, no matter how many assemblies may have been held, in the preparation of pay-rolls only those assemblies for which Armory Drill pay is authorized should be entered on the pay-roll. If the

REPORT OP THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 61 number of assemblies held during a quarter exceeds the number for which Federal Armory Drill pay has been authorized, only the par - ticular assemblies for which such pay is claimed may be entered upon the pay roll. 4. The responsibility for the selection of such assemblies rests with the various organization commanders and the individual mem - bers must abide by this selection, the presumption being that all mem - bers of any organization have been notified through advance publica - tion of training schedules as to which assemblies are to be used for computation of pay. (See Par. 18, NGR. 45). To illustrate, assume a company has held sixteen ordered assemblies in a quarter on dates as follows: January 2, 9, 16, 23, 31, February 6, 13, 20, 22, 28, March 4, 11, 18, 21, 26, 31. Assume further that at each assembly the strength requirements for Armory Drill pay purposes have been met; that 12 assemblies have been authorized for the quarter by the Militia Bureau, and that the organization commander has selected the 12 assemblies for entry on the pay-roll. Assuming further that he has selected the five held dur - ing January, those held on February 6, 13, 20 and 28, and those held on March 11, 18, and 26, only these assemblies may be considered as "authorized assemblies." The officers belonging to the organiza - tion may use only these assemblies for qualifying for Armory Drill pay and no enlisted man may be paid for any assembly he may have attended on any date other than the dates selected. C. C. HAMMOND, Major General, Chief, Militia Bureau." BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska.

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 62 STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN October 25, 1927. Circular Letter No. 28. Subject: Examinations of Candidates for West Point. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, Nebraska National Guard. 1. The following letter from the Adjutant General of the Army, dated August 19, 1927, addressed to the Governor of Nebraska, is published for the information and guidance of all concerned. Ap - plications for this examination should reach this office not later than November 3, 1927, to enable us to prepare for the competitive ex - aminations which will be held November 9th to November 12th, 1927, inclusive. WASHINGTON AG 051.11 West Point (8/19/27) Off. August 19, 1927. The Governor of Nebraska Lincoln, Nebraska. My dear Governor: The regulations for the selection of enlisted men of the National Guard for appointment to the United States Military Academy provide that the candidates shall be apportioned among the States, Territories and the District of Columbia according to the enlisted strength of their respective National Guard organizations. Candidates from the States and Territories will be selected by the respective Governors thereof from successful competitors in a preliminary examination of a scope and nature similar to the regular examination for entrance to the Military Academy, to be instituted and conducted by the Gov - ernors, and to be held between November 1 and November 15 of each year. Under the statute authorizing these appointments, the Governors are restricted in their choice of candidates to enlisted men of the National Guard who conform to the requirements mentioned. To be eligible for appointment from the National Guard, an ap - plicant must be an enlisted man of a unit recognized by the Federal Government. He must, on the date of admission, July 2, 1926, have served as an enlisted man not less than one year, must be between the ages of nineteen and twenty-two years and must be not less than

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 63 five feet four inches in height. The age and service requirements are statutory and cannot be waived or modified, but it is not essential that the service be continuous, so that former service in the Guard may be counted in determining an applicant's eligibility. Similarly, service with a National Guard organization prior to its recognition by the Federal Government, may be considered, the date of enlist - ment of the soldier governing, and not that of the recognition of the unit. The requirements for admission to the Military Academy are fully set forth in the inclosed pamphlet, a supply of which is being sent you under separate cover for distribution to those concerned. The candidates so selected will be authorized by the War Depart - ment to report for the regular entrance examination, which is sched - uled to be held beginning on March 6, 1928, and the appointments available on July 2, 1928, will be awarded to the qualified candidates in the order of merit established at that examination, which is com - petitive among all National Guard candidates. You are, therefore, requested to select, in accordance with the fore-going, one candidate from among the enlisted men of the National •Guard of your State, and to designate him for the entrance examina - tion mentioned, using therefor the inclosed blank form. These cadet - ships being awarded as a result of competition, alternates cannot be considered. There is no limitation to the number who may compete in the preliminary examination and it is suggested that this matter be widely advertised throughout the National Guard organizations of your State so that every enlisted man who is eligible as to age and length of service may be afforded this great opportunity. In the past, some States have failed to take advantage of the opportunity to designate candidates, while other States have desig - nated their full quotas and are constantly asking for the privilege of making more appointments. As a result it has been decided to re - quire that designations shall be made promptly following the No - vember preliminary examination, and in no case later than December 15, 1927. When sending in your designations, it is requested that you inform the Department as to the number of other desirable can - didates, if any, you may have available. The allotments of those States which allow the opportunity to lapse through failure to fill their quotas by December 15, 1927, will be given to other States. Very respectfully, BY DIRECTION OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. LUTZ WAHL, 2 incls. Major General."

Subject: Disposition of other funds. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, Nebraska National Guard. 1. It is desired that a decision be arrived at as to the distribution of the funds which were taken from the Nebraska units who served

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 75 during the World War and which was recently turned back to the State of Nebraska. Your attention is invited to previous communica - tions, one of which was dated some time in May and one some time in October 1927, which gives information regarding this fund and about which we have held several meetings of the Commanding Officers of organizations with a desire to arrive at a conclusion as to a just and equitable method of distribution. 2. We must first take into consideration the fact that none of the present units have contributed a single dollar towards this fund and that it rightfully belongs to the men who served during the World War but it comes back to us as reconstituted units, on account of its being impossible to reach those to whom the fund more prop - erly belongs and along this line we should take into consideration the desires of those men, many of whom are dead and gone and of whom there is nothing but a memory left. 3. If this money is pro-rated and distributed among the pres - ent units, a share would of necessity be deducted for future organ - izations, which would leave the amount to us pro-rated and distributed so small that no one unit would derive much benefit; so the problem which now arises is how to dispose of this money so that it will be equitably made use of, so that those who created the fund will be satisfied and so it will insure the greatest benefit to the present mem - bers of the National Guard and those who are as rightfully entitled to same who join up in the future. 4. Since our organization, there have been numerous changes in units which greatly complicate a division of this fund. For instance, one unit will shortly be demobilized because of lack of support in that particular community; it was necessary to muster out three other units on account of lack of officer material to continue the organiza - tions and, after old units are mustered out, new units will be mustered in, so the question arises as to whether or not it would be fair to the persons who happened to be members at this particular time to ex - pend same and make no provision for those future members who will be as justly entitled to it. 5. After numerous conferences of the respective Commanding Officers with this office, we have concluded that a much more equit - able and just use of this money can be made through the building of a Memorial Recreation building on our camp grounds at Ashland. The fund is just about adequate to construct a very suitable building which could be used by the entire personnel of the camp each year. This building would have a large auditorium, dance hall, stage, read-

76 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL ing and lounge rooms, a large balcony overlooking the river together with rooms for a hostess and visitors to the camp; this would give the present personnel immediate benefit and would 'be a benefit for the entire National Guard for all time to come. We have had an architect draw up a rough outline of what this building is to be and in case we can get a copy of same in time it will be inclosed with this letter, otherwise, we will send it at the earliest possible date. 6. The building of a Memorial, in memory of the World War soldiers who created this fund for us, has the approval of Col. Amos Thomas, 134th Infantry, Col. David C. Hilton, 110th Medical Regi - ment, Maj. Marcus L. Poteet, 35th Division Train, and all junior field Officers who have met with us from time to time in our deliberations. 7. It is desired that the Commanding Officer of each unit and sub-unit present this matter to the personnel of his command at the first meeting after receipt of this letter and communicate the attitude of the command on this subject to this office. The matter should be fully explained to the men as to just what the fund is, its source, and the fact that a rather inequitable division and unsatisfactory arrangement, lacking permanency, would necessarily result if the fund is to be pro-rated to the several organizations. It also should be explained to them that the Recreational building would be a per - manent addition to the camp and would be a continuous benefit to them. While the Commanding Officers of the several organizations and this office feel that a Recreational building would be of much greater permanent value, it is felt that this matter should be taken up with the unit Commanders and their personnel and their attitude de - termined before any final decision is made. 8. There is inclosed herewith for your guidance and benefit a copy of form to fill in for the minutes of your next meeting and a certificate to fill out as to action taken on same and which should be sent to this office at the earliest possible date. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. To: All Unit Commanders and All Field and Staff Officers, Ne - braska National Guard. 1. The dates of the annual encampment, 1928, having been set, i. e., August 6th to 20th, 1928, inclusive, no organization will be excused from attending except when they do not comply with the provisions of Section III, National Guard Regulations 45, 1927. At this point you are cautioned as to the absolute necessity of making yourselves conversant with the above quoted section and citations contained therein as non compliance therewith will cause forfeiture of pay of Company Officers. 2. All units will be notified direct by the United States Property and Distribusing Officer as to the exact hour of departure from home station, rations, handling of baggage, train schedules, transportation requests, bills of lading, making of vouchers, etc. 3. Company Commanders are authorized to purchase one day's travel ration for enlisted men at one dollar and twenty cents per ration, and will follow instructions received from the USP & DO per - taining thereto. 4. Travel Discipline. The senior line officer will assume com - mand of the train and see that travel discipline is maintained; i. e., no men on top of cars or on platform, men not permitted to get off trains at stations without orders, and men's personal appearance and conduct must be correct. All officers will familiarize themselves with Chapter IX, Movements By Rail, Field Service Regulations, 1923. The Commanding Officer will make a thorough inspection of the train before troops entrain at home station, and after they detrain at camp, and report to the Camp Commander immediately upon arrival any defects or faults found with railroads transporting troops. 5. Travel Uniform. Enlisted men will wear woolen O. D. shirts, cotton breeches, service hats with hat cords sewn on, issue leggins and issue shoes. Officers will wear the uniform prescribed for them. Company Commanders will not permit enlisted men to bring civilian.

REPORT OP THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 85 clothing to camp this year as they will not be permitted to wear them on leaves or otherwise during the fifteen day training period. 6. Equipment. Enlisted men will carry prescribed individual and special equipment and the contents of the pack as shown in Training Regulations 50-80 and 50-90. Extra blankets, clothing, shoes, toilet articles, etc., and the bed sack and mosquito bars will be taken by each individual as personal baggage in the barrack bag. Company Commanders should check each enlisted man to see that he provides himself with extra underwear, socks, towels, tooth brush, paste, hand soap, etc., and that he has extra issue clothing; i. e., cotton blouse, breeches and O. D. shirt. 7. Additional Equipment. Organizations should carry as excess baggage (freight) organization equipment consisting of axes, water bags, G. I. cans, colors, field desk, lanterns, marking outfits, rakes, ranges, typewriters, shovels, tools and all cleaning materials; all tentage of whatsoever nature, including poles and stakes therefor together with latrine screens and poles. Information pertaining to saddles, saddle equipment and harness will be furnished in a sep - arate Circular Letter. No target material will be brought to camp as it will be furnished there. All tentage, G. I. cans, rakes, ranges and shovels will be stored in the respective kitchens at the Rifle Range this year, which will do away with the necessity of hauling same back and forth at each camp. Spring cots will be furnished upon arrival at camp and they will also be stored in the mess halls. 8. Ordnance. All ammunition except the initial alowances, 1928, and the cal. .22 long rifle, will be brought to camp and turned in to the USP & DO, securing memorandum reecipt for same. All empty cartridges, (brass), in packing boxes, Belgian aiming devices, all arm racks and lockers, all rifles and pistols and in fact, all arms with which each respective organization is equipped together with all other ordnance with which the individual and Companies are equipped, excepting Machine Gun Companies, which will bring two machine gun carts and two ammunition carts, also excepting the Howitzer Company, which will bring one mortar cart, one mortar ammunition cart, and one 37mm gun carriage. However, these organizations will bring all guns to camp. 9. Special Equipment. All Signal, Medical and Engineer prop - erty, including lister bags, is to be carried. 10. Records. All records and office supplies will be taken; 1. e., Property Records, Individual Records, Stationery, Service Records,

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 86 Morning Reports, all text books, all blank forms on hand, and Score Books. A list in dupli - cate of all officers and men absent from camp, with a statement as to cause of such absence, will be turned in immediately upon arrival in camp. Telegraphic reports of strength when entraining are NOT required this year. 11. Messes. All Company Officers will mess with their organiza - tion and should provide themselves with tables and chairs. Every effort should be made to secure the best possible cooks and Mess Sergeants, as a good mess is one of the most important things to - ward contentment and good morale of an organization. The Com - manding Officer, 134th Infantry, and the Commanding Officer, 110th Medical Regiment, together with the Commanding Officer, 35th Divi - sion Train, Q. M. C, will establish Officers' messes for the Field and Staff Officers of their own organizations and such Officers of the State Staff and Instructors, as may be assigned thereto for mess purposes. STEIN, Major QMC-NNG., USP & DO — Nebraska STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT NEBRASKA July 16, 1928. Circular Letter No. 21. Subject: Physical Condition of Enlisted men. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders. 1. Each year there have been brought to camp men who were not physically fit and who required operations of different kinds and, upon requesting that same be taken care of at camp, we have so far taken care of them. These men have been of no particular value to the service as a whole and have been an additional burden and ex - pense to both the State and Federal Government; so, commencing with this year, the only operative cases that will be taken care of during camp will be for conditions that have not previously existed but have been brought about in line of duty. 2. Each year a number of venereal cases have been brought to camp and there treated. These men are of no value to the service, are a burden upon the State and Federal Government and endanger the health of the other men.

96 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL S. Unit and Sub-unit Commanders will advise their commands that commencing this year no venereal cases will be permitted in camp, that a rigid physical examination will be given all men upon their arrival at camp, and any man found with a venereal disease will be returned to bis borne station at his own expense, without pay or al - lowances, and will be required to refund both railroad fair and sub - sistence expended on him in bringing him to camp. 4. Unit and Sub-unit Commanders will make every effort to ascertain that his men are physically fit before bringing them to camp and that they do not come under the heads mentioned above and will read this letter to his command at every armory drill between the time of receipt of same and the time of entraining at camp. The following letter, dated August 11, 1928, from the Comptroller General of the United States, to the Chief, Militia Bureau, is pub - lished for the information and guidance of all concerned: "Your attention is invited to the fact that the oaths on numerous armory drill pay rolls in .the accounts of Finance Officers were administered by persons acting in an official char-

106 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL acter other than a Summary Court Officer without showing any evidence of authority to administer oaths. Paragraph 34, N. G. STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN November 6, 1928. Circular Letter No. 31. Subject: Examinations of Candidates for West Point. To: All Unit and Sub-unit Commanders, Nebraska National Guard. 1. The annual preliminary examination for the selection of one - enlisted man of the Nebraska National Guard to take the competitive examination for appointment to the United States Military Academy will take place at the Adjutant General's Office beginning November 12, 1928, at 9:00 A. M. 2. To be eligible for appointment from the National Guard, an applicant must be an enlisted man of the unit recognized by the Federal Government. He must, on the date of admission, July 1, 1929, have served as an enlisted man not less than one year, must be between the ages of 19 and 22 years and must be not less than 5' 4" in height. The age and service requirements are statutory and con - not be waived or modified, but it is not essential that the service be continuous, so that former service in the Guard may be counted in determining an applicant's eligibility. The requirements for admis - sion to the Military Academy are fully set forth in the inclosed pamphlet. 3. The candidate selected will be authorized by the War De - partment to report for the regular entrance examination, which is scheduled to be held beginning on March 5, 1929 and the appoint-

108 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL menta available on July 1, 1929, will be awarded to the qualified candidate in the order of merit established at the examination, which is competitive among all National Guard candidates. 4. Previously, applicants have presented themselves to this office to take this examination who were in no way qualified and could not hope to pass the rigid examination given. Company Commanders will make any members of their command who have a desire to take this examination conversant with the requirements of the inclosed pamphlet, and while some believe that a High School graduate can pass this examination, it has been demonstrated that unless they have had at least one year in college, in addition to their High School education, it will be time wasted. 5. Owing to a shortage of funds, it will be impossible for the State to pay any part of the expenses of applicants in coming in for this examination. 6. The return of this pamphlet is requested. H. J.
